qas.question: What specific type of disease is TB?
What type of cells gather around infected macrophages in a person infected with TB?
What type of cell forms when macrophages clump together trying to kill off the TB infection?
What's the technical term for abnormal cell death?
What natural defensive response is hindered by cells in granulomas that can't send antigen to lymphocytes?
What is used by bacteria to destroy the host's immune system?
Which cells serve as antigen to lymphocytes?
What is the texture of cheese called?

context: Tuberculosis is classified as one of the <a0_0>granulomatous inflammatory<a0_0/> diseases. Macrophages, T lymphocytes, B lymphocytes, and fibroblasts aggregate to form granulomas, with <a1_0>lymphocytes<a1_0/> surrounding the infected <b5_0>macrophages<b5_0/>. When other macrophages attack the infected macrophage, they fuse together to form <b6_0>a giant <a2_0>multinucleated<a2_0/> cell<b6_0/> in the alveolar lumen. The granuloma may prevent dissemination of the mycobacteria and provide a local environment for interaction of cells of the immune system. However, more recent evidence suggests that the bacteria use the <b7_0>granulomas<b7_0/> to avoid destruction by the host's immune system. <b8_0>Macrophages and dendritic<b8_0/> cells in the granulomas are unable to present antigen to lymphocytes; thus the <a4_0>immune response<a4_0/> is suppressed. Bacteria inside the granuloma can become dormant, resulting in latent infection. Another feature of the granulomas is the development of abnormal cell death (<a3_0>necrosis<a3_0/>) in the center of tubercles. To the naked eye, this has the texture of soft, white cheese and is termed <b9_0>caseous necrosis<b9_0/>.
